channel.title: Messier Program on Astronomy
channel.description: Recent content in Messier Program on Astronomy

item.title: M74 - Pisces Galaxy
item.description:
M74 - Pisces Galaxy

Spiral galaxy also known as the Phantom Galaxy. Extremely faint - took multiple attempts over two seasons to finally observe.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M74 - Pisces Galaxy
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 5
Lat/Lon: 35.150, -85.326
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 75.0x (24mm eyepiece)
Date: 2024-10-22
Time: 11:39 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

All but the faintest of faint smudges in the sky. Low contrast with no structure visible to me.

item.title: M83 - Southern Pinwheel
item.description:
M83 - Southern Pinwheel

Tiny bright center and very diffuse elsewhere. Symmetrically circular but can’t make out structure of arms.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M83 - Southern Pinwheel
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 34.63, -85.44
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 30.0x (25mm eyepiece)
Date: 2024-05-29
Time: 11:25 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Tiny bright center and very diffuse elsewhere. Symmetrically circular but can’t make out structure of arms.

Additional Notes

Used Telrad finder to locate this object.

item.title: M77 - Cetus Galaxy
item.description:
M77 - Cetus Galaxy

Spiral galaxy also known as Cetus A. Perfectly round with tight bright core and hazy halo.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M77 - Cetus Galaxy
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 4
Lat/Lon: 35.150, -85.326
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 83.3x (9mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-12-06
Time: 9:57 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

M77 looked perfectly round with a tight bright core. In the eyepiece around the core the rest of the galaxy resembled the halo you see around bright objects when obscured by haze.

item.title: M30 - Capricornus Cluster
item.description:
M30 - Capricornus Cluster

Jellyfish Cluster observed from Standing Stone State Park on an exceptional night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M30 - Capricornus Cluster
Seeing: E
Transparency: 7
Lat/Lon: 36.47, -85.41
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 83.3x (9mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-10-10
Time: 7:53 CST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Typical nice bright center of stars, but the outer diffused stars are not as uniform. Looks like a dark shape eats into the bottom (in the eyepiece) of the cluster. Most surrounding stars are few and faint. Except for two: a gold star at 2:00 relative to M30 and a smaller blue star at 9:00.

item.title: M33 - Triangulum Galaxy
item.description:
M33 - Triangulum Galaxy

Spiral Galaxy observed from Standing Stone State Park on an exceptional night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M33 - Triangulum Galaxy
Seeing: E
Transparency: 7
Lat/Lon: 36.47, -85.41
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 30.0x (25mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-10-10
Time: 8:42 CST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Large fuzzy and very uniform in brightness, but dimmer than I think a magnitude 5-6 should be. No structure to the eye. In the eyepiece a trail of stars runs from the right of M33 upward.

item.title: M72 - Aquarius Cluster
item.description:
M72 - Aquarius Cluster

Globular cluster with mostly uniform brightness and tiny bright center. Observed from Standing Stone SP.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M72 - Aquarius Cluster
Seeing: E
Transparency: 7
Lat/Lon: 36.47, -85.41
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 83.3x (9mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-10-10
Time: 8:10 CST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Mostly uniform in brightness with a tiny bright center at best.

Additional Notes

Nearby stars to the right in the eyepiece helped identify the target. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M73 - Aquarius Asterism
item.description:
M73 - Aquarius Asterism

Asterism of four bright stars resembling a pizza slice. Stands out due to lack of nearby stars.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M73 - Aquarius Asterism
Seeing: E
Transparency: 7
Lat/Lon: 36.47, -85.41
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 150.0x (10mm eyepiece + 2x Barlow)
Date: 2023-10-10
Time: 8:18 CST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

M73 does pop out because of the lack of nearby stars. The four bright stars look like a pizza slice to me.

item.title: M76 - Little Dumbbell
item.description:
M76 - Little Dumbbell

Planetary nebula with pill-like shape. O3 filter revealed dumbbell structure clearly.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M76 - Little Dumbbell
Seeing: E
Transparency: 7
Lat/Lon: 36.47, -85.41
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 83.3x (9mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-10-10
Time: 8:26 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Looks like a little pill with a heavier left side in the eyepiece.

Additional Notes

O3 filter made the dumbbell shaped structure evident to the eyes. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M18 - Sagittarius Cluster
item.description:
M18 - Sagittarius Cluster

Black Swan Cluster observed from SM Soccer Fields on a good night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M18 - Sagittarius Cluster
Seeing: G
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 31.3x (24mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-08-15
Time: 10:33 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Small but recognizable as an object with the star clouds in the area. Brightest stars form an egg shaped oval.

item.title: M24 - Sagittarius Star Cloud
item.description:
M24 - Sagittarius Star Cloud

Small Sagittarius Star Cloud observed from SM Soccer Fields on a good night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M24 - Sagittarius Star Cloud
Seeing: G
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 31.3x (24mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-08-15
Time: 10:33 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Star cloud is brilliant with the super wide angle eyepiece. The brightest stars are scattered throughout but the cloud resembles sand with so many stars.

item.title: M26 - Scutum Cluster
item.description:
M26 - Scutum Cluster

Open Star Cluster observed from SM Soccer Fields on a good night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M26 - Scutum Cluster
Seeing: G
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 75.0x (10mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-08-15
Time: 10:20 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Only the 4 brightest stars of the cluster were visible. Looks like a squished kite. Surround star field is dim and sparse.

item.title: M39 - Cygnus Cluster
item.description:
M39 - Cygnus Cluster

Open Cluster observed from SM Soccer Fields on a good night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M39 - Cygnus Cluster
Seeing: G
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 46.9x (16mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-08-15
Time: 9:26 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Very large and open cluster. Half the stars are the brightest and the other half are dimmer at about the same magnitude.

item.title: M54 - Sagittarius Cluster
item.description:
M54 - Sagittarius Cluster

Very dense globular cluster with a bright core and faint disc visible at high magnification.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M54 - Sagittarius Cluster
Seeing: G
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 93.8x (16mm eyepiece + 2x Barlow)
Date: 2023-08-15
Time: 9:48 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Under low magnification, looks like a faint star. Very dense cluster with a bright core and faint disc under high magnification.

item.title: M56 - Lyra Cluster
item.description:
M56 - Lyra Cluster

Globular cluster with grainy appearance indicating some resolved stars. Core not as bright as others.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M56 - Lyra Cluster
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 46.9x (16mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-08-15
Time: 10:47 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Core not as bright as other observed tonight. But entire cluster is grainy indicating some stars are resolved.

item.title: M75 - Sagittarius Cluster
item.description:
M75 - Sagittarius Cluster

Very tight globular cluster appearing like an unfocused star. Bright core with fuzzy disc at high magnification.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M75 - Sagittarius Cluster
Seeing: G
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 93.8x (16mm eyepiece + 2x Barlow)
Date: 2023-08-15
Time: 10:01 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Like M54, very tight cluster making it look like an unfocused star. At the high magnification a brighter core emerges with fuzzy disc around it.

item.title: M29 - Cygnus Cluster
item.description:
M29 - Cygnus Cluster

The Cooling Tower observed from SM Soccer Fields on a very good night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M29 - Cygnus Cluster
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 7
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 46.9x (16mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-07-12
Time: 12:45 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

At first the brightest stars in the cluster looked like an upside down basket. Then I noticed the common name for this DSO - The Cooling Tower. Yep, that’s what it looks like.

item.title: M71 - Sagitta Cluster
item.description:
M71 - Sagitta Cluster

Globular cluster also known as the Angelfish Cluster. Very dim and small with plentiful surrounding stars.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M71 - Sagitta Cluster
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 7
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 53.6x (14mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-07-12
Time: 12:06 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Very dim and small.

Additional Notes

Surrounding stars are plentiful though. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M11 - Wild Duck Cluster
item.description:
M11 - Wild Duck Cluster

Open Cluster observed from SM Soccer Fields on a very good night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M11 - Wild Duck Cluster
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 7
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 46.9x (16mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-07-11
Time: 11:17 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Very tight open cluster that looks halfway globular. Could still see the texture of individual stars in the cluster however. Very Interesting.

item.title: M16 - Eagle Nebula
item.description:
M16 - Eagle Nebula

Star Forming Nebula observed from SM Soccer Fields on a very good night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M16 - Eagle Nebula
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 46.9x (16mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-07-11
Time: 1:09 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Fainter nebula than others I’ve observed on the Messier list. But the O III filter helps define the cloud. Looks triangular. There are a few visible stars in the cloud and even those are not as bright as others within nebula.

item.title: M17 - Swan Nebula
item.description:
M17 - Swan Nebula

Emission Nebula observed from SM Soccer Fields on a very good night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M17 - Swan Nebula
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 46.9x (16mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-07-11
Time: 1:02 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

This nebula is elongated (the Swan body I suppose) with an “M” asterism underneath it in the eyepiece.

item.title: M20 - Trifid Nebula
item.description:
M20 - Trifid Nebula

Emission Nebula observed from SM Soccer Fields on a very good night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M20 - Trifid Nebula
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 46.9x (16mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-07-11
Time: 12:15 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Uniformly sized and the use of a O III filter made the cloud easily visible.

Additional Notes

Seen with M21 as well; just stunning! Used 8x42 binoculars as well which also brought M8 into view at the same time! Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M21 - Sagittarius Cluster
item.description:
M21 - Sagittarius Cluster

Webb’s Cross observed from SM Soccer Fields on a very good night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M21 - Sagittarius Cluster
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 46.9x (16mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-07-11
Time: 12:15 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

A smaller but still nice open cluster at the end of Webb’s Cross opposite M20.

Additional Notes

Seen with M20 as well; just stunning! Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M22 - Sagittarius Cluster
item.description:
M22 - Sagittarius Cluster

Great Sagittarius Star Cluster observed from SM Soccer Fields on a very good night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M22 - Sagittarius Cluster
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 7
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 46.9x (16mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-07-11
Time: 11:46 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Very big globular cluster that is pretty even in brightness to the naked eye. Sparse starfield but a few bright ones at the edge of FOV.

item.title: M23 - Sagittarius Cluster
item.description:
M23 - Sagittarius Cluster

Mattas’ Bat observed from SM Soccer Fields on a very good night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M23 - Sagittarius Cluster
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 46.9x (16mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-07-11
Time: 1:23 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Stars are dim for an open cluster. One star stands out though to the west in the eyepiece.

item.title: M25 - Sagittarius Cluster
item.description:
M25 - Sagittarius Cluster

Alligator’s Foot observed from SM Soccer Fields on a very good night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M25 - Sagittarius Cluster
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 46.9x (16mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-07-11
Time: 1:28 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Nice bright stars within this cluster. Not the most showy or dazzling open cluster but not the worst either.

item.title: M27 - Dumbbell Nebula
item.description:
M27 - Dumbbell Nebula

Planetary Nebula observed from SM Soccer Fields on a very good night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M27 - Dumbbell Nebula
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 7
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 46.9x (16mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-07-11
Time: 11:55 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

With the O III filter the nebula was bright and the center structure was visible. Nice surrounding starfield with bright stars.

item.title: M28 - Sagittarius Cluster
item.description:
M28 - Sagittarius Cluster

Globular Cluster observed from SM Soccer Fields on a very good night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M28 - Sagittarius Cluster
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 7
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 46.9x (16mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-07-11
Time: 11:51 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Tiny and fuzzy but easily recognized. Surrounding stars are very dim and sparse.

Additional Notes

Used Telrad finder to locate this object.

item.title: M55 - Sagittarius Cluster
item.description:
M55 - Sagittarius Cluster

Large globular cluster, also known as Specter Cluster. Faint and fuzzy with sparse surrounding starfield.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M55 - Sagittarius Cluster
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 31.3x (24mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-07-11
Time: 1:47 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Really large globular cluster even with a lesser power. Still faint and fuzzy though.

Additional Notes

Extremely sparse surrounding starfield. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M69 - Sagittarius Cluster
item.description:
M69 - Sagittarius Cluster

Globular cluster appearing as tiny fuzzy ball. Sparse surrounding starfield with prominent line feature.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M69 - Sagittarius Cluster
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 53.6x (14mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-07-11
Time: 1:36 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Tiny fuzzy ball as most globulars are around this magnification.

Additional Notes

Surrounding starfield is sparse but a couple prominent ones cut a line through M69. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M70 - Sagittarius Cluster
item.description:
M70 - Sagittarius Cluster

Very faint and tiny globular cluster. Viewed with Messier’s Quadruplet in same field of view.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M70 - Sagittarius Cluster
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 53.6x (14mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-07-11
Time: 1:40 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Cluster is very faint and tiny.

Additional Notes

Sparse starfield with very dim and small stars. Was able to include the nearby Messier’s Quadruplet in the FOV. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M8 - Lagoon Nebula
item.description:
M8 - Lagoon Nebula

Emission Nebula observed from SM Soccer Fields on a very good night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M8 - Lagoon Nebula
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 31.3x (24mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-07-11
Time: 12:35 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Another stunning object. O III filter brought out the cloud nicely with a trail of bright stars to the left in the eyepiece. The cloud has a dark streak bifurcating it.

item.title: M92
item.description:
M92

Nice bright center that dissipates to the edges. Best of the globulars in my opinion.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M92
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 7
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 53.6x (14mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-07-11
Time: 11:36 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Nice bright center that dissipates to the edges.

Additional Notes

Best of the globulars in my opinion. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M107 - The Crucifix Cluster
item.description:
M107 - The Crucifix Cluster

Not as tight as other globular clusters & faint!!

My Observation Details
Object Name: M107 - The Crucifix Cluster
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 53.6x (14mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-07-10
Time: 11:52 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Not as tight as other globular clusters & faint!!

Additional Notes

Sparse starfield but 3 bright stars in a triangle below target in the eyepiece. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M14 - Ophiuchus Cluster
item.description:
M14 - Ophiuchus Cluster

Lonely Cluster observed from SM Soccer Fields on a very good night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M14 - Ophiuchus Cluster
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 46.9x (16mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-07-10
Time: 11:58 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Slightly loose fuzzy glob. Medium density starfield with some bright stars.

Additional Notes

Used Telrad finder to locate this object.

item.title: M19 - Ophiuchus Cluster
item.description:
M19 - Ophiuchus Cluster

Globular Cluster observed from SM Soccer Fields on a very good night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M19 - Ophiuchus Cluster
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 46.9x (16mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-07-10
Time: 11:23 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Tight cluster with a prominent string of bright stars above and to the left in the eyepiece. M19 is relatively bright compared to other globulars.

item.title: M62 - Ophiuchus Cluster
item.description:
M62 - Ophiuchus Cluster

Globular cluster also known as the Flickering Globular Cluster. Tight fuzzy appearance.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M62 - Ophiuchus Cluster
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 107.1x (14mm eyepiece + 2x Barlow)
Date: 2023-07-10
Time: 10:52 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Tight fuzzy cluster.

Additional Notes

Surrounding starfield is plentiful but dim. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M7 - Ptolemy Cluster
item.description:
M7 - Ptolemy Cluster

Open Cluster observed from SM Soccer Fields on a very good night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M7 - Ptolemy Cluster
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 31.3x (24mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-07-10
Time: 11:35 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

So pretty! Widely dispersed starfield that fills the 24mm eyepiece well.

Additional Notes

Used Telrad finder to locate this object.

item.title: M9 - Ophiuchus Cluster
item.description:
M9 - Ophiuchus Cluster

Globular Cluster observed from SM Soccer Fields on a very good night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M9 - Ophiuchus Cluster
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 46.9x (16mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-07-10
Time: 11:45 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Tight fuzzy cluster. Starfield is sparse. What stars are there are very dim. Noticeably less bright than M9 observed earlier tonight.

item.title: M10 - Ophiuchus Cluster
item.description:
M10 - Ophiuchus Cluster

Globular Cluster observed from SM Soccer Fields on an exceptional night, though with reduced transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M10 - Ophiuchus Cluster
Seeing: E
Transparency: 3
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 75.0x (10mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-06-13
Time: 11:36 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Just a fuzzy spot though, can’t make out the stars in cluster. A little fuzzier than M12 that was found nearby even though it is technically brighter; presumably because it is lower in the sky altitude wise.

item.title: M12 - Ophiuchus Cluster
item.description:
M12 - Ophiuchus Cluster

Gumball Cluster observed from SM Soccer Fields on an exceptional night, though with reduced transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M12 - Ophiuchus Cluster
Seeing: E
Transparency: 3
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 75.0x (10mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-06-13
Time: 11:31 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Nice little cluster with a few standout stars near the center.

Additional Notes

Found the surrounding star patterns with binoculars first. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M5 - Serpens Cluster
item.description:
M5 - Serpens Cluster

Rose Cluster observed from SM Soccer Fields on an exceptional night, though with reduced transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M5 - Serpens Cluster
Seeing: E
Transparency: 3
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 150.0x (10mm eyepiece + 2x Barlow)
Date: 2023-06-13
Time: 10:20 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

At this magnification the cluster should nicely filled the eyepiece, but the transparency greatly reduced the dimmer stars. Identified 5 Serpentis near the cluster.

item.title: M100 - Blowdryer Galaxy
item.description:
M100 - Blowdryer Galaxy

Extremely faint and tiny galaxy in Coma Berenices.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M100 - Blowdryer Galaxy
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 30.0x (25mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-05-10
Time: 12:41 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Extremely faint and tiny.

Additional Notes

Hopped from M98. Used a lower power to identify surrounding star patterns. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M102 - Spindle Galaxy
item.description:
M102 - Spindle Galaxy

Tiny, tiny little ball of faint fuzz.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M102 - Spindle Galaxy
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 75.0x (10mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-05-10
Time: 1:13 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Tiny, tiny little ball of faint fuzz.

Additional Notes

Used the star chart and directions in 110 Things to See… with 25mm eyepiece first to identify surrounding star patterns. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M68 - Hydra Cluster
item.description:
M68 - Hydra Cluster

Globular cluster that’s brighter than galaxies but still a dense smudge. Relief after galaxy observations!

My Observation Details
Object Name: M68 - Hydra Cluster
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 75.0x (10mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-05-10
Time: 12:59 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Generally brighter than galaxies but still a dense smudge.

Additional Notes

Positioned the Telrad 3 times according to the star chart in “110 Things to See…” book, and every time found the same object. Glad to see star clusters again after all those galaxies. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M88
item.description:
M88

All these tiny galaxies in Markarian’s Chain are challenging.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M88
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 75.0x (10mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-05-10
Time: 12:01 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

All these tiny galaxies in Markarian’s Chain are challenging. Everyone is tiny and faint in the 8-9 visual magnitude.

Additional Notes

Hopped from M86 in Markarian’s Chain. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M91
item.description:
M91

Viewing this galaxy more “top down”, but very tiny and faint still.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M91
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 75.0x (10mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-05-10
Time: 12:15 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Viewing this galaxy more “top down”, but very tiny and faint still.

Additional Notes

Triangulated with M90 & M88 to find this galaxy. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M98
item.description:
M98

A 10th magnitude object. Extremely faint and thin.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M98
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 30.0x (25mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-05-10
Time: 12:30 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

A 10th magnitude object. Extremely faint and thin. Probably on the most extreme edge of capability for this scope under the skies where I live.

Additional Notes

Moved across 6 COM from M99 to find this galaxy. Kept 6 Com in the eyepiece with M98. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M99 - Virgo Pinwheel
item.description:
M99 - Virgo Pinwheel

Extremely faint and tiny galaxy in Coma Berenices.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M99 - Virgo Pinwheel
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 30.0x (25mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-05-10
Time: 12:25 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Extremely faint and tiny. Kept 6 Com in view with the galaxy.

Additional Notes

Hopped from M86. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M58 - Virgo Galaxy
item.description:
M58 - Virgo Galaxy

Barred spiral galaxy in the Virgo Cluster. Tiny and faint like most galaxies.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M58 - Virgo Galaxy
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 75.0x (10mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-05-09
Time: 11:20 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Another tiny target and like 99% of galaxies barely a smudge.

Additional Notes

Hopped from M59 as part of the Virgo Cluster observations. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M59 - Virgo Galaxy
item.description:
M59 - Virgo Galaxy

Elliptical galaxy in the Virgo Cluster. Very tiny and faint, viewed with M60.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M59 - Virgo Galaxy
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 75.0x (10mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-05-09
Time: 11:11 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Very tiny and very, very faint. Takes time to make sure what I’m seeing.

Additional Notes

Viewed with M60 in the eyepiece with two brighter stars between the two galaxies. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M60 - Virgo Galaxy
item.description:
M60 - Virgo Galaxy

Elliptical galaxy, one of the brightest in the Virgo Cluster. Starting point for Virgo observations.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M60 - Virgo Galaxy
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 30.0x (25mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-05-09
Time: 11:02 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Tiny and faint. But even in the 8th magnitude of brightness it is going to be one of the brightest galaxies in the Virgo Cluster.

item.title: M84
item.description:
M84

Tiny little smudge in the sky within Markarian’s Chain.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M84
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 30.0x (25mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-05-09
Time: 11:53 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Tiny little smudge in the sky within Markarian’s Chain.

Additional Notes

Hopped from M87 during the Virgo Cluster observations; Observed with M86. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M86
item.description:
M86

Tiny smudge next door to M84 in Markarian’s Chain.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M86
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 30.0x (25mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-05-09
Time: 11:53 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Tiny smudge next door to M84.

Additional Notes

Hopped from M87; Observed with M84. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M87
item.description:
M87

Another tiny smudge in the Virgo Cluster. Home to a supermassive black hole!

My Observation Details
Object Name: M87
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 75.0x (10mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-05-09
Time: 11:46 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Another tiny smudge.

Additional Notes

Hopped from M89. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M89
item.description:
M89

Tiny smudge found using the “basket” star pattern.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M89
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 75.0x (10mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-05-09
Time: 11:32 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Tiny smudge.

Additional Notes

Hopped from M58. Initially identified “basket” star pattern with M90 as well to locate this galaxy. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M90
item.description:
M90

Identified within the “basket” asterism along with M89.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M90
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 30.0x (25mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-05-09
Time: 11:38 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Galaxies were of course very very faint. Identified “basket” asterism with star chart that M90 & M89 are found in.

Additional Notes

Also noted a “w” asterism inside the basket as well & included that in my sketch. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M104 - Sombrero Galaxy
item.description:
M104 - Sombrero Galaxy

Could still see the sombrero personality of this galaxy even though it’s a faint smudge.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M104 - Sombrero Galaxy
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 4
Lat/Lon: 35.150, -85.326
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 75.0x (10mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-04-21
Time: 12:08 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Even though these galaxies are almost always faint smudges, I could still see the sombrero personality of this galaxy.

item.title: M85
item.description:
M85

Tiny smudge, took about an hour to find because of sparse/faint surrounding stars.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M85
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 4
Lat/Lon: 35.150, -85.326
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 30.0x (25mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-04-20
Time: 11:53 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Tiny smudge, but kept my power low to see surrounding stars for identification.

Additional Notes

Hopped from Denebola. Still took about an hour to find because the surrounding stars and patterns were sparse/faint. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M3 - Canes Venatici Cluster
item.description:
M3 - Canes Venatici Cluster

Globular Cluster observed from SM Soccer Fields on an exceptional night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M3 - Canes Venatici Cluster
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 150.0x (10mm eyepiece + 2x Barlow)
Date: 2023-04-19
Time: 12:13 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Because of the exceptional night & brightness of this target, I was able to use 150x magnification to bring out the stars in the cluster!

item.title: M105
item.description:
M105

Part of the M96 group; very faint but visible on this exceptional night!

My Observation Details
Object Name: M105
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 30.0x (25mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-04-18
Time: 11:20 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Very faint but M105 was easily visible on this exceptional night!

Additional Notes

Observed as M96 group. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M106
item.description:
M106

Galaxy was very easy to spot thanks to the quality of tonight’s sky!

My Observation Details
Object Name: M106
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 60.0x (25mm eyepiece + 2x Barlow)
Date: 2023-04-18
Time: 10:37 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Faint but the familiar smudge characteristic of galaxies was flat.

Additional Notes

Found on 1st try by following observation tips. Galaxy was very easy to spot thanks to the quality of tonight’s sky! Observed with 2x barlow and 10mm Plossl as well. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M109 - Vacuum Cleaner Galaxy
item.description:
M109 - Vacuum Cleaner Galaxy

Extremely faint and tiny galaxy near Phecda.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M109 - Vacuum Cleaner Galaxy
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 60.0x (25mm eyepiece + 2x Barlow)
Date: 2023-04-18
Time: 10:29 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Extremely faint and tiny.

Additional Notes

Observed with 10mm & 2x barlow also. Kept Phecda out of view so light from star didn’t affect eyesight. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M49 - Virgo Cluster
item.description:
M49 - Virgo Cluster

Elliptical Galaxy observed from SM Soccer Fields on an exceptional night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M49 - Virgo Cluster
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 30.0x (25mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-04-18
Time: 11:34 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Very tiny object and very faint too. But looks like a flattened circle.

Additional Notes

Still surprisingly easy to find with the observation tips from John Read’s 110 Things to See With a Telescope book and the sky quality tonight. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M61 - Virgo Galaxy
item.description:
M61 - Virgo Galaxy

Spiral galaxy also known as the Swelling Spiral. At edge of scope’s visibility.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M61 - Virgo Galaxy
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 30.0x (25mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-04-18
Time: 11:56 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Tiny and really faint. Can’t say much else about these galaxies.

Additional Notes

At 9.7 magnitude, it’s just on the edge of what this scope can see in this sky. Hopped from Porrima to find this target. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M64 - Black Eye Galaxy
item.description:
M64 - Black Eye Galaxy

Spiral galaxy with elongated shape. Easier to spot being higher in the sky. Meteor sighting during observation!

My Observation Details
Object Name: M64 - Black Eye Galaxy
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 30.0x (25mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-04-18
Time: 10:57 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Elongated fuzzy that leans to the right in the eyepiece.

Additional Notes

A Lyriad meteor went through the middle of the eyepiece when observing this target. This galaxy, being higher in the sky, was noticeably easier to spot than M106 I observed earlier in the evening. Observed with 10mm Plossl too. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M95
item.description:
M95

Part of the M96 group. Very faint but visible on this exceptional night!

My Observation Details
Object Name: M95
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 30.0x (25mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-04-18
Time: 11:20 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Very faint but M105 and 96 were easily visible on this exceptional night!

Additional Notes

Observed as M96 group. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M96
item.description:
M96

Central galaxy of the M96 group, observed with M95 and M105.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M96
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 30.0x (25mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-04-18
Time: 11:20 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

M96 was easily visible on this exceptional night! M105 and M95 were in the same view. All very faint as galaxies tend to be in this sky.

Additional Notes

Observed as M96 group. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M101 - Pinwheel Galaxy
item.description:
M101 - Pinwheel Galaxy

Visually larger than other galaxies but surprisingly dim. Can’t see structures.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M101 - Pinwheel Galaxy
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 5
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 30.0x (25mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-04-16
Time: 11:00 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Visually larger than other galaxies. Can’t see structures. Surprisingly dim considering I have seen dimmer targets more easily.

Additional Notes

Hopped from Mizar & Alcor to find this target. Finally after 2-3 attempts on other nights. Had to wait for clouds to pass. Observed with 10mm Plossl too. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M51 - Whirlpool Galaxy
item.description:
M51 - Whirlpool Galaxy

Spiral galaxy observed from SM Soccer Fields. Tiny target with limited contrast at low magnification.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M51 - Whirlpool Galaxy
Seeing: E
Transparency: 3
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 30.0x (25mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-03-30
Time: 11:07 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

With the 25mm eyepiece, not a lot of contrast but it allowed me to see star patterns to verify. Tiny target to spot even if this galaxy is on its side.

item.title: M53 - Coma Cluster
item.description:
M53 - Coma Cluster

Globular cluster observed at high magnification, showing gradation from bright center to edges.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M53 - Coma Cluster
Seeing: E
Transparency: 3
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 150.0x (10mm eyepiece + 2x Barlow)
Date: 2023-03-30
Time: 10:52 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

A tinier globular with some gradation from the brighter center to the edges.

Additional Notes

Hopped from Vindemiatrix in Virgo via Telrad widths to find this cluster. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M63 - Sunflower Galaxy
item.description:
M63 - Sunflower Galaxy

Spiral galaxy that required patience to locate. Fuzzy elongated patch with nearby stars.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M63 - Sunflower Galaxy
Seeing: E
Transparency: 3
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 60.0x (25mm eyepiece + 2x Barlow)
Date: 2023-03-30
Time: 10:42 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Eventually identified nearby stars to positively id the fuzzy elongated patch that is this target.

Additional Notes

Took much patience scanning the sky. Could identify two nearby stars that my astro software doesn’t have a name for. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M108 - Surfboard Galaxy
item.description:
M108 - Surfboard Galaxy

The faintest of faint smudge - used every trick to see it!

My Observation Details
Object Name: M108 - Surfboard Galaxy
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 4
Lat/Lon: 35.150, -85.326
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 150.0x (10mm eyepiece + 2x Barlow)
Date: 2023-03-15
Time: 10:52 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

I found the faintest of faint smudge and confirmed by a pattern of stars nearby I was looking at M108.

item.title: M44 - Beehive Cluster
item.description:
M44 - Beehive Cluster

The Beehive observed from my home location on a very good night.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M44 - Beehive Cluster
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 4
Lat/Lon: 35.150, -85.326
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 30.0x (25mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-03-15
Time: 9:47 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Really large object that fills up even the lowest power eyepiece I have.

Additional Notes

Matched groups of stars to identify cluster. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M65 - Leo Galaxy
item.description:
M65 - Leo Galaxy

Spiral galaxy observed from home. Very thin appearance, making it easier to identify.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M65 - Leo Galaxy
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 4
Lat/Lon: 35.150, -85.326
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 75.0x (10mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-03-15
Time: 11:18 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

M65 is very thin.

Additional Notes

High in the sky, therefore a darker sky and a bit more contrast. Made finding this and nearby M66 easier to find than other observations tonight. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M66 - Leo Galaxy
item.description:
M66 - Leo Galaxy

Spiral galaxy observed from home. Slightly bigger and brighter than nearby M65.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M66 - Leo Galaxy
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 4
Lat/Lon: 35.150, -85.326
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 75.0x (10mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-03-15
Time: 11:18 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

A little bigger and brighter than nearby M65. Still very faint and without structure in the scope though.

Additional Notes

Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M67 - Cancer Cluster
item.description:
M67 - Cancer Cluster

Open cluster also known as the King Cobra Cluster. Evenly distributed stars with identifiable groupings.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M67 - Cancer Cluster
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 4
Lat/Lon: 35.150, -85.326
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 75.0x (10mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-03-15
Time: 9:38 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Evenly distributed open cluster with a few groups of stars to match and identify cluster. Not the brightest of the open clusters.

item.title: M40 - Winnecke 4
item.description:
M40 - Winnecke 4

Double Star observed from my home location on a very good night.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M40 - Winnecke 4
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 4
Lat/Lon: 35.150, -85.326
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 75.0x (10mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-02-22
Time: 9:58 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Yep, just two stars hanging out together; rather dim.

Additional Notes

Identifies object via surrounding star pattern. Interestingly, I note Stellarium has the magnitude of these two an order dimmer than the book I’m using for the Messier list has them. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M97 - Owl Nebula
item.description:
M97 - Owl Nebula

Aided with the use of an Oxygen III filter, but could not see the structures that give it the owl look.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M97 - Owl Nebula
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 4
Lat/Lon: 35.150, -85.326
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 75.0x (10mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-02-22
Time: 10:26 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Could not see the structures that give it the owl look.

Additional Notes

Aided with the use of an Oxygen III filter. Could not find nearby M108 with the sky conditions. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M1 - Crab Nebula
item.description:
M1 - Crab Nebula

Supernova Remnant observed from my home location on a very good night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M1 - Crab Nebula
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 5
Lat/Lon: 35.150, -85.326
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 75.0x (10mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-02-13
Time: 10:53 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Very high in sky at observation. Cloud is pretty faint with no discernable structure. Confirmed surrounding star pattern with chart in book.

item.title: M46 - Puppis Cluster
item.description:
M46 - Puppis Cluster

Winter Double Cluster observed from my home location on a very good night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M46 - Puppis Cluster
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.150, -85.326
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 30.0x (25mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-02-13
Time: 10:11 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Extremely faint but noticeable while panning.

Additional Notes

Confirmed by finding a pair “frame stars” and 140 Pup. Neat seeing the nearby M47 paired together. Not in the same view, but a short pan away. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M47 - Puppis Cluster
item.description:
M47 - Puppis Cluster

Winter Double Cluster observed from my home location on a very good night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M47 - Puppis Cluster
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.150, -85.326
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 30.0x (25mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-02-13
Time: 10:11 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Has bright stars than it’s neighbor, M46. KQ Pup with it’s sibling star can be seen in the same view.

item.title: M48 - Hydra Cluster
item.description:
M48 - Hydra Cluster

Open Cluster observed from my home location on a very good night.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M48 - Hydra Cluster
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 5
Lat/Lon: 35.150, -85.326
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 30.0x (25mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-02-13
Time: 10:38 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

The stars in the actual cluster seem pretty small and sparse.

Additional Notes

Looked at the wrong side of C Hya for a long time in an attempt to star hop. After correcting, immediately found M48. Confirmed by panning back to 1,2, and C Hya. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M50 - Monoceros Cluster
item.description:
M50 - Monoceros Cluster

Heart Shaped Cluster observed from my home location on a very good night.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M50 - Monoceros Cluster
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 5
Lat/Lon: 35.150, -85.326
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 75.0x (10mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-02-13
Time: 9:50 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Many stars in the background.

Additional Notes

Confirmed heart shape of the bright stars and sketched it in the book. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M78 - Orion Nebula
item.description:
M78 - Orion Nebula

Reflection nebula also known as Casper the Friendly Ghost. Very faint with two stars forming “eyes”.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M78 - Orion Nebula
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 5
Lat/Lon: 35.150, -85.326
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 30.0x (25mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-02-13
Time: 9:23 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Faintest glow under tonight’s condition and can see two stars that are Casper’s eyes.

Additional Notes

Finally could confirm this on a 3rd try. No moon in sky. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M79 - Lepus Cluster
item.description:
M79 - Lepus Cluster

Globular cluster appearing as very tight cluster resembling a faint circular cloud.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M79 - Lepus Cluster
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 5
Lat/Lon: 35.150, -85.326
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 30.0x (25mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-02-13
Time: 9:08 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Very tight cluster of stars that look like a faint circular cloud.

Additional Notes

Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M93 - Winter Butterfly Cluster
item.description:
M93 - Winter Butterfly Cluster

To me the main cluster looks like an old man with a mustache.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M93 - Winter Butterfly Cluster
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 5
Lat/Lon: 35.150, -85.326
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 50.0x (15mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-02-13
Time: 11:13 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

To me the main cluster looks like an old man with a mustache.

Additional Notes

Looked at wrong neighboring star 1st, but after correcting found immediately! Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M41 - Canis Major Cluster
item.description:
M41 - Canis Major Cluster

Little Beehive Cluster observed from my home location on a fair night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M41 - Canis Major Cluster
Seeing: F
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.150, -85.326
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 30.0x (25mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-02-10
Time: 1:17 AM EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Wide open cluster that fills the eyepiece. 12 CMa, a red star, is very apparent near the middle.

item.title: M15 - Pegasus Cluster
item.description:
M15 - Pegasus Cluster

Globular Cluster observed from SM Soccer Fields on a good night.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M15 - Pegasus Cluster
Seeing: G
Transparency: 5
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 75.0x (10mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-01-01
Time: 7:45 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

About average size and fuzzy. A couple brighter stars share the view.

Additional Notes

Waxing gibbous moon washes out the view a bit but is far from the target. Misidentified Enif at first for star hopping, but after correcting easy enough to find. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M2 - Aquarius Cluster
item.description:
M2 - Aquarius Cluster

Nameless Cluster in Aquarius observed from SM Soccer Fields on a good night.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M2 - Aquarius Cluster
Seeing: G
Transparency: 5
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 150.0x (10mm eyepiece + 2x Barlow)
Date: 2023-01-01
Time: 7:18 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Moon washes out the contrast so the edges of the cluster are not visible, but the bright center is visible.

item.title: M52 - Cassiopeia Cluster
item.description:
M52 - Cassiopeia Cluster

Open cluster observed during waxing gibbous moon. Also known as the Salt-and-Pepper Cluster.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M52 - Cassiopeia Cluster
Seeing: G
Transparency: 5
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 75.0x (10mm eyepiece)
Date: 2023-01-01
Time: 7:59 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

None of the stars in M52 are particularly bright so this is just a fuzzy dot.

Additional Notes

Waxing gibbous moon present. Two brightest stars in proximity helped identify; one being 4 Cas. Used Telrad finder.

item.title: M103 - Traffic Light Cluster
item.description:
M103 - Traffic Light Cluster

A very distinct red star in the middle of this cluster.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M103 - Traffic Light Cluster
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 75.0x (10mm eyepiece)
Date: 2022-12-29
Time: 7:20 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

A very distinct red star in the middle of this cluster.

Additional Notes

Thus the common name of Traffic Light Cluster even if the color is out of order. Used Red Dot finder.

item.title: M31 - Andromeda Galaxy
item.description:
M31 - Andromeda Galaxy

Spiral Galaxy observed from SM Soccer Fields on an exceptional night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M31 - Andromeda Galaxy
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 30.0x (25mm eyepiece)
Date: 2022-12-29
Time: 7:33 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Just a hazy center with no visible arms extending; disappointing for a first visual look at this target.

Additional Notes

A long photo exposure with my phone brought out more disk but still no structure. Used Red Dot finder.

item.title: M32 - Andromeda Companion
item.description:
M32 - Andromeda Companion

Dwarf Galaxy observed from SM Soccer Fields on an exceptional night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M32 - Andromeda Companion
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 30.0x (25mm eyepiece)
Date: 2022-12-29
Time: 7:33 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Just a tiny faint speck off the edge of M31.

Additional Notes

Viewed alongside M31. Used Red Dot finder.

item.title: M34 - Perseus Cluster
item.description:
M34 - Perseus Cluster

Spiral Cluster observed from SM Soccer Fields on an exceptional night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M34 - Perseus Cluster
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 30.0x (25mm eyepiece)
Date: 2022-12-29
Time: 8:52 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Long time to confirm the hourglass like shape of stars in the main part of the cluster. But it looks like it sits tilted to the right.

item.title: M35 - Gemini Cluster
item.description:
M35 - Gemini Cluster

The Shoe-Buckle Cluster observed from SM Soccer Fields on an exceptional night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M35 - Gemini Cluster
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 75.0x (10mm eyepiece)
Date: 2022-12-29
Time: 8:27 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Saw the “basket” structure of four brightest stars clearly. Dimmer stars look like they are poured out of the basket.

item.title: M36 - Auriga Cluster
item.description:
M36 - Auriga Cluster

The Pinwheel Cluster observed from SM Soccer Fields on an exceptional night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M36 - Auriga Cluster
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 75.0x (10mm eyepiece)
Date: 2022-12-29
Time: 8:04 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

The brightest stars look like a broom to me.

Additional Notes

Open clusters are my favorite type of DSOs. They remind me of Christmas lights. Used Red Dot finder.

item.title: M37 - Auriga Cluster
item.description:
M37 - Auriga Cluster

Warbird Cluster observed from SM Soccer Fields on an exceptional night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M37 - Auriga Cluster
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 75.0x (10mm eyepiece)
Date: 2022-12-29
Time: 7:59 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

The stars which stand out to me make an asterism that looks like a slingshot.

Additional Notes

Rest of surrounding starfield is very dim. Used Red Dot finder.

item.title: M38 - Auriga Cluster
item.description:
M38 - Auriga Cluster

Starfish Cluster observed from SM Soccer Fields on an exceptional night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M38 - Auriga Cluster
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 30.0x (25mm eyepiece)
Date: 2022-12-29
Time: 8:15 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

The bright stars in this form a distinct arm that pointed to the right during this observation.

Additional Notes

Found this about 10 minutes after M36. Used Red Dot finder.

item.title: M42 - Orion Nebula
item.description:
M42 - Orion Nebula

Nebula observed from SM Soccer Fields on an exceptional night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M42 - Orion Nebula
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 60.0x (25mm eyepiece + 2x Barlow)
Date: 2022-12-29
Time: 9:03 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

WOW!! The nebula is huge! Easily seen in the scope with M43 nearby. Looks like a giant wing.

item.title: M43 - Orion Region
item.description:
M43 - Orion Region

De Mairan’s Nebula observed from SM Soccer Fields on an exceptional night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M43 - Orion Region
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 60.0x (25mm eyepiece + 2x Barlow)
Date: 2022-12-29
Time: 9:03 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Isolating it in the eyepiece helps the cloud pop out a little bit more because M42 is so large and bright. Very circular in shape.

item.title: M45 - Pleiades
item.description:
M45 - Pleiades

Open Cluster observed from SM Soccer Fields on an exceptional night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M45 - Pleiades
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 30.0x (25mm eyepiece)
Date: 2022-12-29
Time: 6:43 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

They shine like jewels in the eyepiece. The 7 stars are bright and vivid.

Additional Notes

Pleiades is easily visible with the eye from my usual observation spots. Used Red Dot finder.

item.title: M6 - Butterfly Cluster
item.description:
M6 - Butterfly Cluster

Open Cluster observed from SM Soccer Fields on a very good night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M6 - Butterfly Cluster
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 75.0x (10mm eyepiece)
Date: 2022-07-23
Time: 11:55 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Nice bright stars spread out. Took a minute to see the butterfly shape.

Additional Notes

Quickly found by moving up from end of Fish Hook to just below the Teapot spout. Used Red Dot finder.

item.title: M81 - Bode's Galaxy
item.description:
M81 - Bode’s Galaxy

A larger galaxy than most visually but still faint. Can’t discern any structure.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M81 - Bode’s Galaxy
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 75.0x (10mm eyepiece)
Date: 2022-07-23
Time: 11:02 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

A larger galaxy than most visually but still faint. Can’t discern any structure.

Additional Notes

Took a lot of patience to see these (M81 & M82). Used Red Dot finder.

item.title: M82 - Cigar Galaxy
item.description:
M82 - Cigar Galaxy

Very faint and structureless irregular galaxy, requiring patience and averted vision.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M82 - Cigar Galaxy
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 75.0x (10mm eyepiece)
Date: 2022-07-23
Time: 11:02 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Very faint and structureless, needed averted vision but still very faint.

Additional Notes

Took a lot of patience to see these (M81 & M82). Used Red Dot finder.

item.title: M94 - Croc's Eye Galaxy
item.description:
M94 - Croc’s Eye Galaxy

Faint but since there is a lack of stars around it stands out easily.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M94 - Croc’s Eye Galaxy
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 75.0x (10mm eyepiece)
Date: 2022-07-23
Time: 10:48 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Faint but since there is a lack of stars around it stands out easily.

Additional Notes

Found a kite pattern of stars with a double star on pattern’s left; pan right to find the galaxy. Used Red Dot finder.

item.title: M13 - Great Hercules Cluster
item.description:
M13 - Great Hercules Cluster

Hercules Star Cluster observed from The Swag, NC on a good night with excellent transparency.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M13 - Great Hercules Cluster
Seeing: G
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.573, -83.093
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 75.0x (10mm eyepiece)
Date: 2022-07-07
Time: 1:45 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

A fuzzy little dot that looks like a smudge. A couple of bright stars around the edge of the eyepiece.

item.title: M4 - Scorpius Cluster
item.description:
M4 - Scorpius Cluster

Crab Cluster observed from SM Soccer Fields on a good night.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M4 - Scorpius Cluster
Seeing: G
Transparency: 5
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 75.0x (10mm eyepiece)
Date: 2022-07-02
Time: 11:05 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Fairly bright for a globular, but very hard to see individual stars in it tonight.

Additional Notes

Cloudy night but found through break in clouds. Also observed with Svbony 6mm. Used Red Dot finder.

item.title: M57 - Ring Nebula
item.description:
M57 - Ring Nebula

First nebula observed! Very circular and obviously stands out amongst the stars.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M57 - Ring Nebula
Seeing: G
Transparency: 5
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 150.0x (10mm eyepiece + 2x Barlow)
Date: 2022-07-02
Time: 11:36 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Wow! Very circular and obviously stands out amongst the stars. I can kinda tell the edges are denser.

item.title: M80 - Scorpius Cluster
item.description:
M80 - Scorpius Cluster

Smaller globular cluster, dense and fuzzy. Framed nicely by two brighter stars.

My Observation Details
Object Name: M80 - Scorpius Cluster
Seeing: G
Transparency: 5
Lat/Lon: 35.161, -85.372
Instrument: 750mm/150mm
Power: 75.0x (10mm eyepiece)
Date: 2022-07-02
Time: 11:22 EST

Observation Notes

Visual Description

A smaller globular, dense and fuzzy. Framed by two brighter stars.

Additional Notes

Cloudy night but seen during break in clouds. Used Red Dot finder.
